questions.stem: A behavior analyst uses an ABAB design to evaluate a token economy intervention. In this design, the second 'A' phase involves:

options.text: Withdrawing the intervention to see if behavior returns to baseline
Replicating the intervention with a new participant

questions.explanation: In the ABAB (reversal/withdrawal) design, A = baseline, B = intervention. The second A phase withdraws treatment to demonstrate experimental control—if behavior returns toward baseline, it supports the causal relationship. The second B phase reintroduces treatment to confirm the effect.

questions.stem: A researcher wants to study the effect of a teaching method on students but cannot withdraw the intervention once learned. The MOST appropriate single-subject design would be:
questions.explanation: Multiple baseline designs are appropriate when withdrawal isn't possible or ethical (learned skills, safety behaviors). The intervention is introduced at different times across behaviors, settings, or participants—staggered introduction demonstrates experimental control without reversal.

questions.stem: In a between-subjects factorial design with two independent variables (therapy type: CBT vs. medication) and (severity: mild vs. moderate vs. severe), how many cells/conditions exist?
questions.explanation: Factorial designs multiply levels: 2 therapy types × 3 severity levels = 6 cells. Each cell represents a unique combination (e.g., CBT-mild, CBT-moderate, CBT-severe, medication-mild, medication-moderate, medication-severe). This allows examination of main effects and interactions.

questions.stem: A study compares three therapy approaches (CBT, psychodynamic, control) on anxiety at pre-treatment, post-treatment, and 6-month follow-up. This is best described as a:

options.text: Mixed (split-plot) design with one between and one within factor

questions.explanation: This is a mixed (split-plot) design: therapy type is between-subjects (different participants in each condition), time is within-subjects (same participants measured repeatedly). This design allows examination of treatment effects, time effects, and treatment × time interactions.

questions.stem: A researcher is concerned that pretest sensitization may interact with the treatment effect. Which design specifically addresses this threat?
questions.explanation: The Solomon four-group design includes: (1) pretest-treatment-posttest, (2) pretest-control-posttest, (3) treatment-posttest only, (4) posttest only. Comparing groups allows detection of pretest sensitization and its interaction with treatment. It's resource-intensive but comprehensive.

questions.stem: Which are TRUE statements about single-subject experimental designs? Select all that apply.

options.text: Each participant serves as their own control
They require fewer participants than group designs
Visual analysis of graphed data is the primary analysis method
They are well-suited for applied behavior analysis

questions.explanation: Single-subject designs: participant is own control, need few participants, CAN establish causality through replication logic, use visual analysis primarily, and are foundational to ABA. They demonstrate functional relationships between IV and DV through within-subject replication.

questions.stem: Which threats to internal validity are controlled by random assignment in a true experimental design? Select all that apply.

options.text: Statistical regression (when not selecting on extreme scores)

questions.explanation: Random assignment equalizes groups on all variables at baseline, controlling selection bias, selection interactions, and regression. History affects all groups equally (controlled by comparison, not assignment). Differential attrition occurs after assignment and isn't prevented by it.

questions.stem: Which features characterize quasi-experimental designs? Select all that apply.

options.text: Participants are NOT randomly assigned to conditions
They are used when random assignment is impractical or unethical
They have weaker internal validity than true experiments
They cannot include control or comparison groups
Nonequivalent control group design is a common example

questions.explanation: Quasi-experiments lack random assignment but can include comparison groups. They're used when randomization isn't feasible (ethical concerns, naturally occurring groups). Internal validity is weaker due to potential selection effects. The nonequivalent control group design is the classic example.

questions.stem: When would a multiple baseline design across behaviors be appropriate? Select all that apply.

options.text: When the behaviors are functionally independent
When reversal of behavior change is not possible
When you want to study multiple behaviors in the same individual
When behaviors are expected to change together (high covariation)
When withdrawal of treatment would be unethical

questions.explanation: Multiple baseline across behaviors requires functional independence—if one behavior changes, others shouldn't. It's ideal when reversal is impossible or unethical. If behaviors covary (change together), staggered introduction can't demonstrate experimental control because untreated behaviors will also change.

questions.stem: A researcher uses a within-subjects design where all participants receive all treatments. What are advantages of this design? Select all that apply.

options.text: Eliminates individual differences as a source of error
Each participant serves as their own control

questions.explanation: Within-subjects advantages: removes individual differences as error, fewer participants needed, increased power, participants as own controls. However, carryover effects are a disadvantage that must be addressed (counterbalancing, washout periods), not an advantage.

questions.stem: Match each single-subject design with its defining characteristic.

columns.text: Two or more treatments rapidly alternated

questions.explanation: ABAB: withdrawal shows experimental control. Multiple baseline: staggered introduction across behaviors/settings/participants. Alternating treatments: rapid switching compares treatments directly. Changing criterion: behavior should match changing criterion level, demonstrating stimulus control.

questions.stem: Match each research design with its classification.

rows.text: Participants randomly assigned to drug vs placebo
Intact classrooms compared after school policy change
Survey of depression and anxiety symptoms

questions.explanation: True experiment: random assignment, manipulation. Quasi-experiment: manipulation without random assignment (intact groups). Correlational: no manipulation, measures associations. Single-subject experimental: demonstrates experimental control through within-subject replication.

questions.stem: For each design, select ALL appropriate uses.
questions.explanation: RCT: gold standard for internal validity. Multiple baseline: ideal when behavior can't be reversed. Nonequivalent groups: used when random assignment impossible. Interrupted time series: ideal for policy evaluation, also used without randomization.

questions.stem: Select ALL threats that each design feature helps control.
questions.explanation: Random assignment controls selection. Control groups rule out history/maturation (affects both groups). Counterbalancing distributes order effects across conditions. Blinding prevents demand characteristics and experimenter expectancy from influencing results.

questions.stem: In a 2 × 2 factorial design, there are {{blank1}} independent variables. This design can test {{blank2}} main effect(s) and {{blank3}} interaction(s). If one factor is between-subjects and one is within-subjects, the design is called a {{blank4}} design.
questions.explanation: A 2 × 2 factorial has 2 IVs, each with 2 levels (4 cells total). It tests 2 main effects (one for each IV) and 1 interaction (how the IVs combine). When one factor is between and one within subjects, it's a mixed/split-plot design requiring special statistical analysis.

questions.stem: The ABAB design demonstrates experimental control through {{blank1}}. If behavior changes from A to B, returns toward baseline in the second A, and improves again in the second B, this provides evidence of a {{blank2}} relationship. This design is INAPPROPRIATE when {{blank3}} or when the behavior {{blank4}}.
questions.explanation: ABAB uses withdrawal/reintroduction logic—repeated demonstration of behavior change establishes functional (causal) relationships. Contraindicated when withdrawal is unethical (e.g., self-injury has decreased) or when behavior can't reverse (learned skills, permanent changes). Use multiple baseline instead.

questions.stem: A school psychologist wants to evaluate whether a social skills intervention improves playground behavior. The intervention cannot be withdrawn once taught, and the psychologist has access to three students with similar social difficulties.

options.text: ABAB design is inappropriate due to irreversibility
Each student can serve as their own control
Random assignment to groups is not feasible
Collect baseline on all three students simultaneously
Introduce intervention to one student at a time at different points
Demonstrate that behavior changes only when intervention is introduced

questions.explanation: Multiple baseline across participants is ideal: irreversible behavior (can't use ABAB), small n (can't do RCT), need experimental control. Implementation: concurrent baselines, staggered introduction. Control is demonstrated when each participant changes only when their intervention begins.

questions.stem: A hospital implements a new hand hygiene protocol. The administrator wants to evaluate its effectiveness but cannot randomly assign units to receive or not receive the protocol for ethical reasons.

options.text: Historical data on infection rates exists
All units must receive the protocol
Collect multiple time points before and after intervention
Look for change in level and/or slope at intervention point
Use historical trend to control for maturation
Compare to a similar hospital without the protocol

questions.explanation: Interrupted time series is ideal for policy/program evaluation when RCT isn't possible. Multiple pre/post measurements allow detection of level changes (immediate effect) and slope changes (trend change). Adding a comparison site strengthens the design (comparative ITS).

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that correctly describe characteristics of TRUE experimental designs.
questions.passage: Experimental designs are the gold standard for establishing causal relationships. [True experiments require random assignment of participants to conditions]. [True experiments must have at least three groups]. [The experimenter manipulates the independent variable]. [True experiments can only be conducted in laboratory settings]. [True experiments control for selection bias through randomization]. [True experiments always use double-blind procedures].

highlightableSegments.text: True experiments require random assignment of participants to conditions
True experiments must have at least three groups
The experimenter manipulates the independent variable
True experiments can only be conducted in laboratory settings
True experiments control for selection bias through randomization
True experiments always use double-blind procedures

questions.explanation: True experiments require: (1) random assignment and (2) manipulation. Two groups are sufficient (treatment vs. control). Field experiments exist. Blinding is desirable but not definitional. The key features are randomization and manipulation for causal inference.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL correct statements about within-subjects (repeated measures) designs.
questions.passage: Within-subjects designs have each participant experience all conditions. [This eliminates between-subject variability as a source of error]. [Fewer participants are needed than in between-subjects designs]. [Practice effects are eliminated in within-subjects designs]. [Counterbalancing can control for order effects]. [Within-subjects designs are always preferable to between-subjects designs]. [The same statistical tests are used for within and between-subjects designs].

highlightableSegments.text: This eliminates between-subject variability as a source of error
Fewer participants are needed than in between-subjects designs
Practice effects are eliminated in within-subjects designs
Counterbalancing can control for order effects
Within-subjects designs are always preferable to between-subjects designs
The same statistical tests are used for within and between-subjects designs

questions.explanation: Within-subjects advantages: eliminates individual differences, fewer participants, counterbalancing controls order. Practice effects are NOT eliminated—they're controlled via counterbalancing. Not always preferable (carryover can be fatal). Different stats needed (repeated measures ANOVA, not independent).

questions.stem: Arrange the phases of an ABAB single-subject design in the correct order.

items.text: A₁: Collect baseline data until stable
B₁: Introduce intervention, continue measurement
A₂: Withdraw intervention, measure return to baseline
B₂: Reintroduce intervention, confirm effect
Evaluate: Did behavior change correspond to phase changes?

questions.explanation: ABAB sequence: baseline (A₁) → treatment (B₁) → withdrawal (A₂) → reinstatement (B₂). Each phase change should produce corresponding behavior change. The withdrawal phase is crucial—if behavior returns toward baseline, it supports causal inference. Reintroduction confirms the effect.

questions.stem: Arrange the steps for conducting a randomized controlled trial (RCT) in the correct sequence.

items.text: Define research question, hypotheses, and design
Recruit participants meeting inclusion/exclusion criteria
Randomly assign participants to treatment or control
Implement treatment/control conditions with fidelity
Collect outcome measures (ideally with blinded assessors)
Analyze data using intent-to-treat principle

questions.explanation: RCT procedure: define study → recruit → randomize → implement → measure → analyze. Random assignment must occur AFTER recruitment but BEFORE treatment. Intent-to-treat analysis includes all randomized participants regardless of completion.

questions.stem: A behavior analyst tracks aggressive behavior across ABAB phases. Review the data.
questions.question: What do these data demonstrate?

options.text: A functional relationship between intervention and behavior

questions.explanation: Classic ABAB pattern: high baseline (A₁=12), reduction with treatment (B₁=4), return toward baseline when withdrawn (A₂=10), reduction when reintroduced (B₂=3). This repeated covariation of behavior with treatment phases demonstrates a functional (causal) relationship.

questions.stem: A researcher examines an interrupted time series following a workplace safety intervention.
questions.question: What pattern in the data would best support a treatment effect?

options.text: The current pattern—immediate level change that is maintained
Gradual decline starting before the intervention
Return to pre-intervention levels by Month 6
High variability across all time points

questions.explanation: This ITS shows ideal treatment effect pattern: stable baseline (~19/month), immediate level change at intervention (drop to 10), maintained/continued improvement post-intervention. A pre-intervention decline would suggest history/maturation. Return to baseline or high variability would undermine causal inference.

questions.stem: Categorize each design as a TRUE EXPERIMENT, QUASI-EXPERIMENT, or SINGLE-SUBJECT EXPERIMENT.

items.text: Participants randomly assigned to CBT vs medication
ABAB reversal design
Nonequivalent control group design
Multiple baseline across behaviors
Solomon four-group design
Interrupted time series
Double-blind placebo-controlled RCT
Changing criterion design

questions.explanation: True experiments: random assignment (RCT, Solomon). Quasi-experiments: no random assignment (nonequivalent groups, ITS). Single-subject: within-subject replication logic (ABAB, multiple baseline, changing criterion). The key distinction is how experimental control is established.

questions.stem: Categorize each scenario by the appropriate single-subject design.

items.text: Testing if removing token reinforcement causes behavior to return to baseline
Teaching reading to three students, starting intervention at different times
Gradually increasing exercise goal from 10 to 30 minutes
Comparing two teaching methods by rapidly switching between them
Treating self-injury where withdrawal would be unethical
Demonstrating control over smoking rate by changing daily limit

questions.explanation: ABAB: can withdraw safely, test reversibility. Multiple baseline: can't/won't withdraw (learning, dangerous behaviors). Changing criterion: shaping, gradual goals. Alternating treatments: compare interventions directly. Match design to research question and practical constraints.
